overview.short: Gemella species are Gram-positive cocci that often appear in pairs, tetrads, or short chains and are part of the normal human mucosal flora.
overview.clinical_context: Occasionally associated with endocarditis, bloodstream infections, and oral or upper respiratory tract infections.

field_notes.Gram Stain: Cells may decolorize easily, sometimes appearing Gram-variable.
field_notes.Shape: Often described microscopically as diplococci or tetrads, resembling Neisseria but Gram-positive.
field_notes.Haemolysis: Haemolytic pattern varies by species and strain.

key_differentiators.notes: Catalase negativity separates Gemella from staphylococci.
Gram-positive reaction differentiates from morphologically similar Gram-negative diplococci.

common_confusions.reason: Shared catalase negativity and coccoid morphology.
Diplococcal arrangement may mimic Neisseria on microscopy.

when_to_question_identification: Catalase positivity suggests Staphylococcus or Micrococcus.
Oxidase positivity suggests Neisseria or Moraxella.
Strict anaerobic growth is inconsistent with Gemella.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Helps separate Gemella from Streptococcus species.
Preferred method due to phenotypic overlap with streptococci.
